context: Kaown et al. (2014b) previously estimated groundwater flow velocities at the study site by means of 3H–3He analysis. The groundwater flow velocities (1.9×10−6 to 2.1×10−5 m/s) estimated around a stream were about ten times slower than those for the main source area (9.8×10−6 to 1.2×10−4 m/s). According to the results from pumping and slug tests conducted in this study, the hydraulic conductivity values range between 2.0×10−4 cm/s and 2.4×10−3 cm/s and values in the area around the stream range between 6.5×10−4 cm/s and 4.2×10–3 cm/s. Previous research has reported that the groundwater at this site is contaminated by multiple DNAPL components, such as trichloroethylene (TCE), chloroform (CF), and tetrachloride (CT) (Yang and Lee, 2012; Kaown et al., 2014a). The main source of the contaminants is located inside the ROA. Local TCE sources of groundwater contaminants exist near GW-10, GW-11, and GW-19 wells, which are located in the downgradient area. Site monitoring and investigation was performed intensively from 2009 to 2013 as part of a research program for the Korea Ministry of the Environment (KMME).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,1,2-trichloroethene and tetrachlorides are both mentioned as contaminants found in groundwater, specifically as components of dense non-aqueous phase liquids (DNAPLs). While they are part of a broader discussion on groundwater contamination, there is no direct interaction or specific relationship detailed between the two compounds beyond their shared presence in the contaminated site.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 2 reflects an indirect connection, as both 1,1,2-trichloroethene and tetrachlorides are identified as contaminants in the same environmental context, but their relationship is not elaborated upon or quantitatively assessed.
